title: Elderly Male with Progressive Hearing Loss and History of Unsuccessful Hearing Aid Use
chief_complaint: The patient's daughter-in-law reports that 'he does not pay attention.' The patient claims people do not speak clearly and that he understands better when they speak slowly.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual onset over the past 15 years.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Social withdrawal; has ceased attending church, parties, and the theater.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Reluctant patient; previous hearing aids were 'useless' to him; no desire to purchase new ones.

history.present_illness: 82-year-old male with a 15-year history of gradually progressive hearing loss. He reports fluctuation in hearing ability. He finds listening in groups difficult.
history.otologic_history: None specified other than progressive loss.
history.prior_management: Has tried several hearing aids in the past which were deemed useless; currently reluctant to try again.
history.patient_goals: Patient is reluctant and brought in by family; he specifically compliments the audiologist for being easier to understand than most people.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral sloping sensorineural hearing loss. Thresholds are symmetrical. No air-bone gaps observed.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT is consistent with pure-tone averages (slightly poorer). Word recognition scores (SRS) are poor to fair, suggesting phonemic regression.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present at expected levels for cochlear loss.

tests.name: ABR
tests.key_findings: All waves normal at high sensation levels (SLs); interpeak latencies normal; latency-intensity function is steep (consistent with cochlear recruitment).

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: TEOAE: Absent. Tone-decay test: Minimal decay (negative for retrocochlear pathology).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, symmetrical, sloping sensorineural hearing loss consistent with presbycusis. Speech recognition scores are disproportionately poor (62% AD, 58% AS) relative to the pure-tone thresholds, indicative of phonemic regression. Immittance, ABR, and tone-decay results rule out conductive or retrocochlear pathology, confirming a cochlear site of lesion.
counseling_points: Acknowledge your frustration with previous hearing aids; technology and fitting strategies have improved.
Your hearing loss involves both volume and clarity (phonemic regression), which explains why hearing aids alone didn't solve the problem previously.
We recommend a trial period with amplification, but success will require auditory rehabilitation and coping strategies, not just the device.
Assistive listening devices (like TV ears or a personal FM system) may help in specific difficult situations where hearing aids struggle.
Family involvement is crucial; we need to teach your family how to speak to you so you can understand them better (slower, facing you).
notes_for_actor: Portray reluctance and skepticism regarding hearing aids.
Be defensive about your attention span ('I pay attention just fine, people just mumble').
Compliment the audiologist on speaking clearly compared to others.
Show signs of social withdrawal/resignation ('I just don't go to parties anymore').
